title: Lamentation for Egypt
shortSummary: Ezekiel 32 presents a prophetic lament over the impending destruction of Egypt, symbolized by Pharaoh and his multitude. The chapter vividly describes God's judgment through the king of Babylon and portrays the downfall of Egypt alongside other nations in the realm of the dead, emphasizing God's sovereignty and justice.
timeline: c. 593 BC - During the Babylonian exile, in the twelfth year of King Jehoiachin's captivity

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The king of Egypt, depicted as a powerful but prideful ruler who will face divine judgment and destruction.

keyCharacters.name: Son of man (Ezekiel)
keyCharacters.description: The prophet Ezekiel, who receives and delivers God's message of lamentation and judgment against Egypt.

keyCharacters.name: King of Babylon
keyCharacters.description: The instrument of God's judgment who will bring destruction upon Egypt and its allies.

keyCharacters.name: Asshur
keyCharacters.description: Representative of Assyria, mentioned among the slain nations in the underworld, symbolizing defeated enemies.

definitions.definition: A poetic expression of sorrow or mourning, often used in the Bible to mourn the destruction of a nation or city.
A biblical phrase referring to the realm of the dead or the underworld, where the deceased reside.
A term used in the Bible to describe those outside the covenant community of Israel, often symbolizing spiritual impurity or separation from God.
A metaphor for executing divine judgment or warfare, indicating God's active role in punishing nations.

outline.heading: God’s Judgment Announced Against Pharaoh
outline.description: God commands Ezekiel to lament over Pharaoh, likening him to a young lion and a whale whose pride and power will be broken by a divine net, symbolizing the Babylonian conquest and the total devastation of Egypt.

outline.heading: The Desolation of Egypt
outline.description: God describes the complete desolation of Egypt, with its land soaked in blood and its inhabitants destroyed, so that all will recognize the LORD’s sovereignty and power.

outline.heading: The Lamentation for Egypt and the Nations in Sheol
outline.description: Ezekiel portrays a vision of the dead nations, including Egypt and its allies, lying uncircumcised and slain in the underworld, emphasizing their shame and defeat, while Pharaoh finds no comfort but shares their fate.

application: Recognize God’s sovereignty over all nations and rulers, trusting His justice even when it involves judgment.
Avoid pride and self-reliance like Pharaoh, submitting humbly to God’s authority in every area of life.
Remember the reality of spiritual death and separation from God for those outside His covenant, motivating us to share the gospel.
Find comfort in God’s righteous judgment, knowing that evil will ultimately be punished and His kingdom established.

keyVerses.text: And when I shall put thee out, I will cover the heaven, and make the stars thereof dark; I will cover the sun with a cloud, and the moon shall not give her light.
keyVerses.significance: This verse powerfully illustrates the totality of God's judgment, symbolizing darkness and the removal of all sources of light and hope for Egypt.

keyVerses.text: When I shall make the land of Egypt desolate, and the country shall be destitute of that whereof it was full, when I shall smite all them that dwell therein, then shall they know that I am the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the purpose of God's judgment: to reveal His identity and sovereignty to all peoples.

keyVerses.text: The strong among the mighty shall speak to him out of the midst of hell with them that help him: they are gone down, they lie uncircumcised, slain by the sword.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the fate of proud nations and leaders who oppose God, showing that might and power cannot prevent judgment and death.
